quiz.title: Chemistry Grade 12: Unit 12 Quiz 6
quiz.subtitle: 12.6: Transition Metals
quiz.subject: Chemistry
quiz.topic: Properties, electron configurations, and oxidation states

questions.question: Which of the following defines a transition metal according to the IUPAC definition?
options: An element whose atom has a partially filled d sub-shell, or which can give rise to cations with an incomplete d sub-shell.
Any element located in the d-block of the periodic table.
An element that only exists in the solid state at room temperature.
An element that has a full s sub-shell and a full d sub-shell.
questions.explanation: This definition excludes Group 12 elements like Zinc, which have full d-shells in both their atomic and common ionic states.

questions.question: What is the correct ground-state electron configuration for Chromium (Cr, Z=24)?
questions.explanation: Chromium is an exception to the Aufbau principle; it gains stability by having a half-filled 4s and 3d sub-shell.

questions.question: When transition metals form ions, which electrons are lost first?
questions.explanation: Even though the (n-1)d sub-shell is filled after the ns sub-shell, the ns electrons are at a higher energy level in the atom and are removed first during ionization.

questions.question: Transition metals are known for having multiple oxidation states. This is primarily because:
options: The energy levels of the ns and (n-1)d sub-shells are very close together.
Their atomic radii are the largest in their respective periods.
They can only form covalent bonds.
questions.explanation: Because the 4s and 3d electrons are close in energy, varying numbers of them can be involved in chemical bonding.

questions.question: Which of the following properties is NOT typical of transition metals?
options: Paramagnetism in many of their compounds.
questions.explanation: Transition metal compounds are famous for their vibrant colors due to d-d electronic transitions; colorless compounds (like Sc³⁺ or Zn²⁺) are the exception.

questions.question: Paramagnetism in transition metal complexes is caused by:
options: The presence of unpaired electrons in the d-orbitals.
The rapid movement of the metal atom in the crystal lattice.
The paired electrons in the s-orbitals.
The high density of the metal nucleus.
questions.explanation: Unpaired electrons have a net magnetic moment. Substances with unpaired electrons are attracted to magnetic fields.

questions.question: Which element is often considered a 'd-block element' but not a 'transition metal'?
questions.explanation: Zinc has a configuration of [Ar] 4s² 3d¹⁰. Its only common ion is Zn²⁺ ([Ar] 3d¹⁰). Since it never has an incomplete d-shell, it technically fails the IUPAC transition metal definition.

questions.question: What is the most common oxidation state for the first-row transition metals (Sc through Zn)?
questions.explanation: Most transition metals (except Scandium) commonly form a +2 ion by losing their two 4s electrons.

questions.question: Which transition metal can reach the highest oxidation state in the first row?
questions.explanation: Manganese can reach a +7 oxidation state (as seen in the permanganate ion, MnO₄⁻) by using all seven of its valence electrons (4s² 3d⁵).

questions.question: Transition metals are effective catalysts because they can:
options: Change oxidation states easily to facilitate electron transfer.
Solidify the reactants into a single mass.
Increase the temperature of the surrounding solution.
Lower the concentration of the reactants.
questions.explanation: Their ability to adopt multiple oxidation states allows them to act as efficient 'shuttles' for electrons in redox-active mechanisms.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You have a strong understanding of transition metal electronic structure.
scoreMessages.70: Good job. Be careful with the exceptions like Cr and Cu.
scoreMessages.50: Satisfactory. Review why ns electrons are lost before (n-1)d electrons.
scoreMessages.0: Focus on electron configurations and the definition of transition metals.
